blocks.title: Basics
blocks.description: JavaScript is a versatile, high-level programming language primarily used to add interactivity to web pages. It is also used in a variety of other environments, including server-side development (Node.js) and mobile app development.

blocks.title: Write in output
blocks.description: JavaScript provides several ways to output data. The most common is using the console for debugging and the DOM (Document Object Model) for displaying content on a webpage.

blocks.title: Console Log
blocks.description: Outputs messages to the browser's developer console. Useful for debugging.
blocks.code: console.log("Hello, JavaScript!");

blocks.title: Alert
blocks.description: Displays a popup alert box in the browser. Generally avoided in modern web development.
blocks.code: alert("This is an alert!");

blocks.title: Writing to the HTML document
blocks.description: Outputs directly to the HTML document. Use with caution, as it can overwrite existing content.
blocks.code: document.write("Hello from document.write!");

blocks.title: Variables
blocks.description: Variables are used to store data in JavaScript. You declare variables using `var`, `let`, or `const`. `let` and `const` are preferred for modern JavaScript.

blocks.title: Variable Declaration with 'var'
blocks.description: Variables declared with `var` have function scope or global scope if declared outside a function.  Avoid using `var` in modern JavaScript.
blocks.code: var oldVariable = 'This is an old variable'; // Avoid using var in newer code

blocks.title: Variable Declaration with 'let'
blocks.description: `let` declares a block-scoped variable. It's the preferred way to declare variables in modern JavaScript when the value might change.
blocks.code:
let newVariable = 'This variable can be reassigned';
newVariable = 'New value'; // Allowed

blocks.title: Variable Declaration with 'const'
blocks.description: `const` declares a block-scoped constant. The value cannot be reassigned after initialization. `const` does not make the content immutable, e.g. when used with objects.
blocks.code: const constantVariable = 'This value cannot be changed';

blocks.title: Constants
blocks.description: Constants are variables whose values cannot be reassigned after they are initialized. Use `const` to declare constants.
blocks.code:
const PI = 3.14159;
// PI = 3.14; // This would cause an error because you can't reassign a constant.

blocks.title: Data Types
blocks.description: JavaScript has several built-in data types. Understanding these is fundamental to working with JavaScript.

blocks.title: String
blocks.description: Represents text.
blocks.code:
let myString = "Hello, world!";
console.log(myString);

blocks.title: Number
blocks.description: Represents numerical values, both integers and floating-point numbers.

blocks.title: Boolean
blocks.description: Represents a logical entity and can have two values: true or false.

blocks.title: Null
blocks.description: Represents the intentional absence of a value. It is an assignment value, meaning it can be assigned to a variable.
blocks.code:
let myNull = null;
console.log(myNull);

blocks.title: Undefined
blocks.description: Represents a variable that has been declared but not assigned a value.
blocks.code:
let myUndefined;
console.log(myUndefined); // Output: undefined

blocks.title: Symbol
blocks.description: Represents a unique and immutable data type, often used as object property keys.

blocks.title: Variable Scope
blocks.description: Understanding variable scope is crucial to avoid unexpected behavior. Scope refers to where a variable is accessible within your code.

blocks.title: Global Scope Example
blocks.description: Variables declared outside of any function have global scope.
blocks.result:
This is a global variable
This is a global variable

blocks.title: Function Scope Example
blocks.description: Variables declared inside a function have function scope, accessible only within that function.

blocks.title: Block Scope Example
blocks.description: Variables declared with `let` or `const` inside a block (e.g., inside an `if` statement or loop) have block scope, accessible only within that block.

blocks.title: Scope with var
blocks.description: Variables declared with `var` inside a function  have function scope, regardless of whether they are declared inside a block or not, `var` does not respect the block scope.

blocks.title: Operators
blocks.description: JavaScript provides various operators to perform operations on values.

blocks.title: Arithmetic Operators Example
blocks.description: Examples for each operator to show the functionalities.
blocks.code:
let addition = 10 + 2; // 12
let subtraction = 10 - 2; // 8
let multiplication = 10 * 2; // 20
let division = 10 / 2; // 5
let modulus = 10 % 3;   // 1
console.log(addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, modulus);

blocks.title: Assignment Operators Example
blocks.description: Shows different ways to assign values to variables.
blocks.code:
let a = 10; 
a += 5;   // a = a + 5;   a is now 15
a -= 3;   // a = a - 3;   a is now 12
a *= 2;   // a = a * 2;   a is now 24
a /= 4;   // a = a / 4;   a is now 6
a %= 5;   // a = a % 5;   a is now 1
console.log(a); // Output: 1

blocks.title: Comparison Operators Example
blocks.description: Examples to compare the variables values
blocks.code:
let x = 5;
let y = '5';

console.log(x == y);  // true (loose equality)
console.log(x === y); // false (strict equality)
console.log(x != y);  // false (loose inequality)
console.log(x !== y); // true (strict inequality)
console.log(x > 3);   // true
console.log(x < 10);  // true
console.log(x >= 5);  // true
console.log(x <= 5);  // true
